title: 111_s1624
content: The Act titled "Medical Bankruptcy Fairness Act of 2009" defines key terms. The "Medical Bankruptcy Fairness Act of 2009" defines terms related to medical debt and medically distressed debtors. The "Medical Bankruptcy Fairness Act of 2009" outlines criteria for debt relief eligibility, including exceeding 10% of adjusted gross income or $10,000 in medical debts, or loss of domestic support income due to a medical issue. The "Medical Bankruptcy Fairness Act of 2009" establishes eligibility criteria for debt relief, including exceeding 10% of adjusted gross income or $10,000 in medical debts, or experiencing a downgrade in employment status due to caring for a sick family member for at least 30 days. Amendments are made to sections 104(b)(1) and 104(b)(2) of title 11, the United States Code. SEC. 3. EXEMPTIONS. Exempt Property: Section 522 of title 11, the United States Code, is amended to allow medically distressed debtors to exempt up to $250,000 in value of real or personal property used as a residence or burial plot. The debtor may elect to exempt up to $250,000 in value of real or personal property, cooperative, or burial plot. Amendments are made to Sections 104(b)(1) and 104(b)(2) of title 11, the United States Code. SEC. 4. DISMISSAL OF A CASE OR CONVERSION TO A CASE UNDER CHAPTER 11 OR 13. Amends Section 707(b) of title 11, prohibiting motions under certain circumstances. SEC. 5. CREDIT COUNSELING. Amends Section 109(h)(4) of title 11 to include medically distressed debtors. SEC. 6. NONDISCHARGEABILITY OF CERTAIN ATTORNEYS FEES. SEC. 6. NONDISCHARGEABILITY OF CERTAIN ATTORNEYS FEES. Amends Section 523(a) of title 11 to include attorneys fees incurred by a debtor from filing a petition under chapter 7. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS. Specifies the effective date and application of the amendments made by this Act. SEC. 8. ATTESTATION BY DEBTOR. SEC. 8. ATTESTATION BY DEBTOR. Any debtor seeking relief as a medically distressed debtor must attest in writing under penalty of perjury that their medical expenses were genuine and not incurred to manipulate the medical bankruptcy provisions.
